abstract.p: Cara Thanassi letter on May 6 Anthony Lewis column says Americans today have same basic desire for justice and peace that fueled protests against Vietnam War

block.p: In his May 6 column, Anthony Lewis writes, ''Americans who were not alive in 1970 must find it hard to understand why students at Kent State and other universities protested so emotionally over Vietnam.''

In his May 6 column, Anthony Lewis writes, ''Americans who were not alive in 1970 must find it hard to understand why students at Kent State and other universities protested so emotionally over Vietnam.''
From the recent Millennium March for equality for gays to the coming Million Mom March against gun violence, Americans of all ages continue to criticize public policy and fight for change.
While these protests did not, and will not, have the intensity and impact that those over Vietnam had, they arise from the same basic desire for justice and peace.

Although 30 years have passed since Kent State, what could possibly be difficult to understand about students' outrage over a futile and brutal war? Mr. Lewis should give those of us under 30 a little more credit.
